channel.title: A quick quetsion about vista
channel.description: Well im getting windows vista home premium soon and I want to know the diffrence between the 36 and 64bit? If i need a certain kind where do i check on my pc..I have all the other requirments. Thanks for the answer. (If I get one.)

item.title: A quick quetsion about vista
item.dc:creator: @Enjoy_me_now Enjoy me now
item.description:
@Enjoy_me_now wrote:

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:17, topic:149824”][quote author=Enjoy me now link=topic=205261.msg1809437#msg1809437 date=1191806156]

Hope you don’t plan to play games on vista… Cause its UBERLY SLOW. My friend went back to xp soon as he got vista install.

lol, vista if great for games, if your friend has both xp and vista on the same computer then the vista is gonna go bad
[/quote]

And why would that be? As long as you have the amount of your ram X 2 in free hard-drive space, there won’t be any performance issues with having multiple pc’s.[/quote]

sometimes the vista and xp interfere with each other so its like it compeates with to be the best.

Read full topic

item.title: A quick quetsion about vista
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Enjoy me now, post:16, topic:149824”][quote author=mrrules link=topic=205261.msg1809000#msg1809000 date=1191799461]
Hope you don’t plan to play games on vista… Cause its UBERLY SLOW. My friend went back to xp soon as he got vista install.
[/quote]

lol, vista if great for games, if your friend has both xp and vista on the same computer then the vista is gonna go bad[/quote]

And why would that be? As long as you have the amount of your ram X 2 in free hard-drive space, there won’t be any performance issues with having multiple pc’s.

item.title: A quick quetsion about vista
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

One of the core differences between 32-bit and 64-bit editions of Windows Vista is of course how much system memory the two variants of Microsoft's latest operating systems can use. You have to understand that Microsoft alone limited 32-bit Vista to a maximum of 4 GB of RAM while taking the high-end editions of 64-bit Vista up to 128 GB of RAM. The fact of the matter is that the company could have tailor fitted both 32-bit Windows Vista and Windows XP to address well in excess of 4 GB of system memory, but didn't. The best argument related to the possibility of introducing support for over 4 GB of RAM with x86 Vista and XP is the fact that Microsoft does feature alternative 32-bit Window operating systems with this characteristic. Case in point Windows Server 2003, Enterprise Edition (32 GB of physical RAM), Windows Server 2003, Datacenter Edition and Windows Server 2003 SP1, Enterprise Edition(64 GB of physical RAM) and Windows Server 2003 SP1, Datacenter Edition (128 GB of physical RAM). All these server side Windows operating systems are 32-bit platforms.
From http://news.softpedia.com/news/32-bit-Windows-Vista-vs-64-bit-Windows-Vista-64312.shtml

I think 64 bit is better, but costs more?

Read full topic
